thread.title: Is the University of Sunderland set to face future financial difficulties?

author: Hannah Graham
title: Is the University of Sunderland set to face future financial difficulties?
text:
Is the University of Sunderland set to face future financial difficulties? The Times Higher Education's financial health check on universities highlighted potential problems for the Wearside institution Share Sunderland University in Sunderland City Centre (Image: Newcastle Chronicle) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! With concerns over falling revenues and nearly a third of its cash coming from foreign students, could the University of Sunderland be facing future financial difficulties? 
In the Times Higher Education (THE) annual ‘university financial health check’, the Wearside institution came up more than once in tables of the universities showing potentially worrying signs. 
Sunderland saw a drop in income of more than 3% in 2015/16, compared to the previous year. More starkly, it lost close to 5% of its income from fees in real terms in that same year. 
According to the paper, the close correlation between a drop in fees and a drop in overall income at universities like Sunderland highlights the importance of cash from students. Sunderland University in Sunderland City Centre (Image: Newcastle Chronicle) 
This means such institutions could struggle to cope with any significant fall in demand for places. 
Yet such a fall is judged by THE experts to be possible over the coming years. 
This year, university applications fell by 4% from UK students, according to UCAS. Fewer people studying degrees means less tuition fees, as well as more competition for the pool of students who do apply. 
THE also claims a “constant worry” over the past few years has been the potential for a stricter visa policy to be introduced, making it harder to recruit international students. 
This worry could be compounded by Brexit, which might affect demand from EU students - already, the number of Europeans planning to take degrees in the UK has fallen by 5%. The Murray Library at Sunderland University in Sunderland City Centre (Image: Newcastle Chronicle) Read More University bosses gather to discuss impact of Brexit on attracting international talent 
Sunderland is among just 15 universities assessed by THE which gains more than a quarter of its income from overseas students. With more than 30% of its cash coming from overseas or EU students, it is among those which could suffer if Britain becomes less attractive to foreign undergraduates. 
University leaders themselves have admitted that the referendum result could have this effect, not just because of immigration arrangements and visa issues, but possibly due to foreign perception of the country. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now 
Speaking to the Education Select Committee in March, Shirley Atkinson, Vice Chancellor of Sunderland University, said: “There is a wider issue about the reputation of British universities in the world now as a result of the Brexit vote. Read More Alan Shearer has a message for Newcastle United fan graduating at the Stadium of Light 
“Unfortunately, it is being played back in some quarters as Britain not being open and prepared to share and not interested in having mobility in students or staff.” 
However, it’s worth noting that alongside its Wearside and London campuses, the University of Sunderland does operate a campus in Hong Kong. This means much of its overseas income comes from students who stay overseas, which means they may be less affected by a lessening of desire to come and live in Britain. 
Another silver lining for Sunderland is its Silver Award for undergraduate provision under the new Teaching Excellence Framework (TEF). 
This scheme was designed to assess the quality of undergraduate teaching in universities and colleges, and Government originally warned that only places who scored silver or gold awards under the framework would be able to charge the highest permitted fees. 
Although this requirement has now been delayed, Sunderland’s high score means is not in danger of being forced to reduce its fees from the new, higher rate of £9,250, which it will be charging from the start of the 2017 academic year. Read More 
The higher rating is also likely to make the institution more appealing to students. 
The University of Sunderland has been contacted for comment. Like us on Facebook
